published_attributes.title: 💡 Intro
published_attributes.serialized_body: As Product Designers, we should never skip the wireframing stage. They are the bridge between researching and designing visuals. Wireframing lets us test-drive ideas and iterate quickly early on. Not only does it save us a bunch of time otherwise wasted on never-ending adjustments, but it also makes our process more solid, our vision clearer, and our rationale more valid, therefore the final design becomes truly meaningful and valuable to the client. The outcome of this phase is usually a set of user flows and wireframes.

blocks.text: As Product Designers, we should never skip the wireframing stage. They are the bridge between researching and designing visuals. The outcome of this phase is usually a set of user flows and wireframes.

published_attributes.title: 💡 Intro
published_attributes.serialized_body:
What you will learn in this chapter

  • Definitions and things client should understand
  • What elements include in the wireframe
  • Best practices - Do’s and Dont’s of wireframing

Questions you should ask yourself before this stage

  • Do I know who will be using the product? (What kind of users?)
  • Do I know what’s their goal?
  • Do I know what problem does this product or feature solve for them?
  • Do I know what are some of the actions or operations they are likely to perform? (workflows)

Which Stakeholders you will need at this stage

  • Client
  • Designer
  • QA

Tools that can help you at this stage

  • Pen & Paper
  • Quick prototyping tool (ie. Figma)

Benefits of this stage

For client

  • Allows for fast prototyping,
  • Allows clients to test ideas early,
  • Allows us to eliminate errors and problems early,
  • The client will know better his product and the user’s needs and behavior patterns.

For Team

  • Wireframes will often help to flush out new requirements and questions that may not have been considered by the project team,
  • Developers will know how website/application will work before PD provides them final designs,
  • Chance to gather feedback &  test the product’s working before proceeding to the design phase.

published_attributes.title: 🤔 Definitions and things client should understand about UX Design
published_attributes.serialized_body:
What is a Wireframe? A wireframe is a basic visual interface guide that suggests the structure of an interface and the relationships between its pages. They serve as a blueprint that defines each project’s structure, content and functionality. Wireframes are created before any visual design work is started so that the focus is on information architecture without the distraction of color and visual elements.

User Flow Diagrams Also known as flowcharts – are a visual representation of a desired user journey path throughout the designed product. They illustrate steps, decisions, and funnels users frequently come across. Thoughtfully crafted User Flow Diagrams let you reveal moments critical for conversion and then apply adequate solutions to identified obstacles. Examples → Link, Link

Low-fidelity wireframes Low fidelity wireframes include the most basic content and visuals and are usually static (not interactive). They are often used to help map out the shell of the interface, its screens and basic information architecture. Example → Link

High-fidelity wireframes Visual guides to page's structure, composition, and information hierarchy. Their purpose is arranging elements of website content in an informed, user-friendly and therefore business effective manner. As their main focus lies in functionality not disturbed by flashy visuals, they shall be stripped from elements of visual language such as colors, infographics, effects etc. Example → Link

blocks.text:
What is a Wireframe?
A wireframe is a basic visual interface guide that suggests the structure of an interface and the relationships between its pages. They serve as a blueprint that defines each project’s structure, content and functionality. Wireframes are created before any visual design work is started so that the focus is on information architecture without the distraction of color and visual elements.

User Flow Diagrams
Also known as flowcharts – are a visual representation of a desired user journey path throughout the designed product. They illustrate steps, decisions, and funnels users frequently come across. Thoughtfully crafted User Flow Diagrams let you reveal moments critical for conversion and then apply adequate solutions to identified obstacles.
Examples → Link, Link

Low-fidelity wireframes
Low fidelity wireframes include the most basic content and visuals and are usually static (not interactive). They are often used to help map out the shell of the interface, its screens and basic information architecture.
Example → Link

High-fidelity wireframes
Visual guides to page's structure, composition, and information hierarchy. Their purpose is arranging elements of website content in an informed, user-friendly and therefore business effective manner. As their main focus lies in functionality not disturbed by flashy visuals, they shall be stripped from elements of visual language such as colors, infographics, effects etc.
Example → Link

published_attributes.title: ✍️ What elements include in the wireframe
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Wireframes should include all the important elements of a Product. These include:

  • 👉 Navigation,
  • 👉 Company logo (if exists),
  • 👉 Content area sections + sample content (placeholder text),
  • 👉 Call to actions,
  • 👉 Widgets,
  • 👉 Fields,
  • 👉 Forms,
  • 👉 Pop-ups,
  • 👉 Hover states (if appropriate).

published_attributes.title: ✅ Best Practices - Do’s and Dont’s
published_attributes.serialized_body:
The main purpose of wireframing is to create visual representation of ideas to support conversations, iteration and rapid ideation. Below is a list of best practices we truly believe in at Netguru

#1 Colors can be distracting, ensure your design remains focused on the experience you’re creating and not the visual design solutions to come.

  • Create your wireframes based on a muted color pallette
  • Use color only if it helps defining the idea behind the design; Even then – limit yourself to as few colors as possible
  • Don’t use color in your wireframe designs unless it has a solid purpose
  • Don’t use various tints of grey; using tinted grey is ok, but stick to one

#2 Be consistent: The best way to facilitate presented solutions is to be consistent in your wireframe designs.

  • Be consistent in visual representation of UI elements (ideally by using reusable elements like Symbols in Sketch )
  • Be aware of font sizes and spacing
  • Sketch your ideas before you start digitalize them - you’ll save a lot of time in the early iteration phase
  • Don’t use different line weights for similar elements
  • Don’t use too many fonts and font sizes

#3 Use real content: writing is a design skill, it will help you understand the client and story better.

  • If you don’t have real content: write it yourself based on competition and own research
  • Use solid grey placeholder elements to represent photos, videos and maps
  • Design for real life cases (i.e don’t assume every surname is max. 10 characters long)
  • Don’t use placeholder text in crucial design elements: like navigation, CTA’s (i.e Lorem Ipsum…)
  • If you need to show a series of data like tables or tiles: be sure not to use the same copy in each of those elements

published_attributes.title: ✅ Best Practices - Do’s and Dont’s
published_attributes.serialized_body:
#4 Never wire alone, the main purpose of having this process is the conversation potential and bigger possibility to discover better solutions than working on your own.

  • Be open for new ideas
  • Before presenting your wireframes to the client grab a few opinions from within your project team: they understand the product and know the client;
  • Always get a second opinion on your solutions (at Netguru we use #tradeguru-design - dedicated Slack channel)
  • Don’t work on the wires alone just to show the client the end result of the whole product. Instead cooperate and exchange ideas on InVision and Slack

#5 Set clear expectations: be sure that the client understands the principle of this process.

  • Tell the client about the outcome before you start designing
  • Communicate clearly, early and often
  • It’s a good idea to have a live call with the client when presenting your wireframes for the first time - this way you have the opportunity to answer all questions and avoid misunderstandings
  • Don’t assume your client knows how to use collaboration tools or that wireframes are not final designs - always educate
  • Don’t leave designs of complicated processes without any comments

#6 Use the right tool for the right job: here at Netguru we do wireframes mostly in Sketch (it’s flexible, easy to use and there is no need to recreate layouts in a different app), but remember not to limit yourself.

  • Use whatever tool you think will fit: for example sketching and whiteboarding
  • Don’t let the software be a barrier

published_attributes.title: ✅ Best Practices - Do’s and Dont’s
published_attributes.serialized_body:
#7 You are not your design.

  • Be prepared to pivot often and embrace rapid ideation
  • Don’t get too attached to your wires, but at the same time also remember to defend ideas that are worth defending

#8 Be selective and keep it simple.

  • Be prepared to pivot often and embrace rapid ideation
  • Don’t get too attached to your wires, but at the same time also remember to defend ideas that are worth defending

#9 Control the conversation.

  • Support your wireframes by controlling the conversation: if things get off track, bring it back around
  • Don’t be afraid to interrupt politely and ask meaningful open-ended questions

#10 Wireframe with final designs in mind.

  • You will save yourself a ton of work if you create your wires with the final designs in mind: reusable components, precise elements and good fonts
  • Talk to your devs about technical effectiveness of your design solutions

published_attributes.title: ❓ Q&A
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Desired outcomes after this stage Clickable Wireframe  - Lo/High fidelity (prefered high-fidelity)

  • User flows covering Jobs To Be Done / User Stories
  • Usage of real content included
  • Designed test scenarios for wireframes
  • Wireframes tested & accepted by client - ready to use in visual design stage

🙋Questions your client may ask at this stage

Can you explain your distinction between wireframe and visual design? (question from real client from NearFine project) Wireframes is a quick visual method of building backbone for the product. In this stage we define how our product/features should work. It also helps us to avoid UX problems and present developers how website/application will work before we provide them final designs. Visual design is part of design process after the wireframing. Now based on wireframes we focus on creating the visual image and style of the product. To sum up – wireframes are needed to work out the backbone of the product and visual design part is to create the look for it. By using both of them we build better products, more adjusted to user’ needs.

Are wireframes just static images? Let's make it testable You’re probably  thinking about prototype which is very simple clickable output where you can test interaction, scenarios and stories at very early stage. It is a tool to check out users’ behavior and product’s functionality.

What kind of benefits can I get from that? Using wireframes will often help to flush out new requirements and questions that may not have been considered by the project team. Wireframes often end up evolving into the requirements for a system. On this stage we can also check if your product covers all needs that users can have. By creating wireframes you will get better product, more adjusted to your target audience.

blocks.text:
Desired outcomes after this stage
Clickable Wireframe  - Lo/High fidelity (prefered high-fidelity)
User flows covering Jobs To Be Done / User Stories
Usage of real content included
Designed test scenarios for wireframes
Wireframes tested & accepted by client - ready to use in visual design stage
🙋Questions your client may ask at this stage

Can you explain your distinction between wireframe and visual design? (question from real client from NearFine project)
Wireframes is a quick visual method of building backbone for the product. In this stage we define how our product/features should work. It also helps us to avoid UX problems and present developers how website/application will work before we provide them final designs.
Visual design is part of design process after the wireframing. Now based on wireframes we focus on creating the visual image and style of the product.
To sum up – wireframes are needed to work out the backbone of the product and visual design part is to create the look for it. By using both of them we build better products, more adjusted to user’ needs.

Are wireframes just static images? Let's make it testable
You’re probably  thinking about prototype which is very simple clickable output where you can test interaction, scenarios and stories at very early stage. It is a tool to check out users’ behavior and product’s functionality.

What kind of benefits can I get from that?
Using wireframes will often help to flush out new requirements and questions that may not have been considered by the project team. Wireframes often end up evolving into the requirements for a system. On this stage we can also check if your product covers all needs that users can have. By creating wireframes you will get better product, more adjusted to your target audience.

published_attributes.title: ❓ Q&A
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Questions you should ask yourself after this stage

  • Are User flows done?
  • Are wireframes available on InVision?
  • Are wireframes clickable?
  • Do wireframes following our best practices?
  • Use of real content
    • Focused on information architecture?
    • Is the wireframe ready to be reused in the visual design phase?
  • Is feedback gathered on #tradeguru-design Slack channel?
